track_1.name: Foundations
track_1.description: Master the basics of GetDeal.ai positioning

lesson.title: The Core Identity
lesson.content: GetDeal.ai is an M&A marketplace for AI companies. NOT a fundraising platform. NOT a job board. We connect AI startups seeking EXITS (full acquisitions or 20%+ stakes) with strategic acquirers, PE firms, and corporates.
key_points: AI companies specifically (Seed to Series B)
Buyers: Corporates, PE, Late-Stage VCs, Family Offices, Funded Companies

persona.name: Alex Thompson
persona.background: 20 years in VC, board member of 12 AI companies
persona.context: Conference networking event, cocktails in hand

scenario.situation: You're at a VC conference. Alex approaches you: 'Hey, I keep hearing about GetDeal.ai but I'm not totally clear on what you guys do. Is it like AngelList or something?'

marketplace_model.description: Explains marketplace connecting buyers and sellers

scenario.ideal_response: Not quite — we're actually the opposite. GetDeal.ai is an M&A marketplace for AI companies. We connect AI startups looking to exit with strategic acquirers, PE firms, and corporates looking to buy. Think curated deal flow, not fundraising. Your portfolio companies that are 3-5 years post-Series A and exploring options? We're their confidential path to acquirers.
common_mistakes: Being too vague about buyer types
Going too long for a cocktail conversation

lesson.title: We're Not Bankers
lesson.content: GetDeal.ai is often compared to investment bankers. Key differences: (1) Success-fee ONLY — no retainers, (2) No exclusivity required, (3) Confidentiality-first design, (4) AI-specific buyer network, (5) Technical due diligence expertise.
key_points: Success-fee only — pay nothing unless we help close
No exclusivity — founders keep their options
Confidentiality-first — team and competitors don't know
Technical DD — we understand AI architectures

persona.name: Maria Chen
persona.context: LinkedIn message, warm intro from mutual connection

scenario.situation: Maria messages you on LinkedIn: 'Hey, I heard about GetDeal.ai from a friend. We're a Series A AI startup doing $800K ARR in healthcare diagnostics. I'm not sure if we should talk to you or just hire a regular investment banker. What exactly do you guys do differently?'

core_differentiators.description: Mentions at least 2 key differences from bankers

scenario.ideal_response:
Hey Maria — great question. Here's the short version: GetDeal.ai is a confidential M&A marketplace — we connect AI companies like yours with strategic acquirers and PE firms looking to buy, not VCs looking to fund.

The difference from a traditional banker?
1. Confidentiality-first — your team won't know you're exploring
2. AI-specific buyers — not generalists
3. Success-fee only, no exclusivity — you pay nothing unless we help you close

Worth a 30-minute confidential call to see if there's fit?

lesson.title: Know Your Buyers
lesson.content: GetDeal.ai serves 5 buyer types: (1) Corporates — M&A/Corp Dev teams at F1000, (2) Private Equity — tech-focused PE doing add-ons, (3) Late-Stage VCs — seeking portfolio exits, (4) Family Offices — direct tech investment, (5) Funded Companies — $5M+ raised, doing acqui-hires.
key_points: Family Offices: Direct investment in AI

persona.name: James Whitfield
persona.background: F500 company, $2B revenue, building AI capabilities

scenario.situation: James replies to your cold outreach: 'Thanks for reaching out. We get pitched by deal sourcing platforms all the time. Most are just aggregators with no real vetting. What makes GetDeal.ai different? We have our own M&A team — why would we need you?'

corporate_value_prop.description: Specific value for corporate M&A teams

buyer_understanding.description: Shows understanding of corporate M&A challenges

scenario.ideal_response:
Fair question — most platforms are aggregators. We're different because we're AI-specific and we vet deeply.

For corporate M&A teams, the value isn't replacing your team — it's extending your pipeline with off-market, pre-vetted AI assets. We handle technical DD (architecture, data moats, IP risks) so your team can focus on strategic fit.

Typically saves 200+ hours per acquisition and surfaces opportunities your team wouldn't see otherwise.

Want me to share a specific example of an AI company in your space that's currently on our platform?

lesson.title: Know Your Sellers
lesson.content: GetDeal.ai sellers are AI companies (Seed to Series B) seeking full exits or 20%+ stakes. They choose us for: confidentiality (team doesn't know), efficiency (we handle the process), expertise (AI-specific), and alignment (success-fee only).
key_points: Stage: Seed to Series B AI companies
Fear: Team finding out, wasting time, wrong buyers
Win: Right acquirer, fair valuation, founder-friendly process

persona.name: David Park
persona.background: Series A, $1.2M ARR, enterprise ML platform, 12 employees
persona.context: Inbound inquiry via website, exploring options

scenario.situation: David submits an inquiry through your website: 'We're a Series A AI company with about $1.2M ARR. I'm starting to think about exit options but I'm worried about confidentiality — if my team finds out I'm exploring, it could cause panic. Also, I've heard horror stories about founders getting lowballed. How does your process work and how do you protect sellers?'

process_explanation.description: Clear explanation of how process works

scenario.ideal_response:
David — those are exactly the right questions to ask, and they're concerns we hear from most founders.

On confidentiality: It's core to how we operate. Your listing starts as an anonymized teaser — buyers see the opportunity without your company name. Only after they sign an NDA and we confirm mutual interest do we reveal identity. Your team never needs to know.

On valuation: We match you with multiple qualified buyers simultaneously. Competition drives fair pricing. And we don't require exclusivity — you keep your options open.

Process is simple: Initial consultation → we vet and build your profile → matched to relevant buyers → introductions → you decide who to engage.

Fee: Success-fee only. You pay nothing unless we help you close.

Want to schedule a confidential 30-minute call to discuss your specific situation?
common_mistakes: Not addressing confidentiality first (it's his main concern)
Not explaining how competition protects valuation
Sounding too salesy given his concerns

train_pool.description: Random scenario pool for /train mode. Never repeats until all exhausted.

persona.name: Sarah Mitchell
persona.background: 10 years at Oracle, leads AI acquisition strategy

scenarios.situation: Sarah says: 'We looked at platforms like yours before. The problem is the companies are usually not enterprise-ready. We need $5M+ ARR minimum and SOC2 compliance. Do you actually have assets at that level?'
scenarios.ideal_response:
Valid concern — enterprise readiness is non-negotiable for Oracle-scale acquisitions. We do have assets at that level, though they're a smaller portion of our pipeline. Our vetting specifically includes compliance status (SOC2, HIPAA where relevant) and revenue verification via QuickBooks/Xero integrations.

Rather than make claims, let me show you: I can share an anonymized profile of a $6M ARR AI company with SOC2 Type II that's currently exploring strategic options. Interested?

scenarios.situation: Cold outreach response: 'We get hundreds of deal sources reaching out. What's your hit rate? How many deals have you actually closed?'
scenarios.ideal_response:
Fair question — we're selective about who we work with for exactly this reason. We're focused on quality over volume.

We're early but building traction: [X] assets currently on platform, [Y] active buyer conversations, [Z] in diligence. For Vista specifically, we've identified 3 AI companies that fit your enterprise software add-on thesis.

Want me to share anonymized profiles? You can judge the quality firsthand.

scenarios.situation: Lisa asks: 'I looked at your fee structure. 7% on the first million seems steep compared to what I've heard about investment bankers. Why should I pay that?'
scenarios.ideal_response:
I get the comparison, but let me break down the actual economics:

Traditional bankers charge $50-100K retainer upfront PLUS 4-6% success fee, require 6-12 month exclusivity, and often don't specialize in AI.

Our model: Zero upfront, success-fee only, no exclusivity. You pay nothing unless we deliver. And at your revenue level, our fee structure is actually lower total cost than most banker engagements.

More importantly: we're aligned. If we don't close a deal that works for you, we make nothing.

Does that help clarify the value?

scenarios.situation: Jennifer says: 'Some of my portfolio companies might be interested, but I'm worried about signaling. If word gets out they're exploring exits, it could hurt their fundraising options. How do you handle that?'
scenarios.ideal_response:
That's the exact concern we're designed for. The process is founder-controlled and confidential:

1. Listing starts anonymized — no company name in initial teaser
2. Buyers sign NDAs before any identifying info shared
3. Founders approve each buyer introduction individually
4. No public presence — nothing shows up in searches

For your portfolio companies specifically: they can explore quietly without any market signal. If they find the right buyer, great. If not, no one knows they were looking.

Want to discuss specific portfolio companies that might benefit?

scenarios.situation: Ryan says: 'We just closed our seed round. Isn't it too early to think about exits? I feel like I should focus on building for now.'
scenarios.ideal_response:
Totally fair — and you're right that building should be the focus right now. We typically work with companies that are 3-5 years post-seed when they're actually ready to explore.

That said, it's worth understanding the landscape early. Knowing what acquirers look for can actually inform how you build — features that drive enterprise value, metrics buyers care about, etc.

No rush on our end. Happy to stay in touch and be a resource when the timing makes sense. Mind if I check in in a year or so?

persona.name: Dr. Amanda Chen
persona.background: PhD Stanford, leads AI acquisition technical DD

scenarios.situation: Amanda says: 'The AI companies we evaluate often have impressive demos but weak fundamentals — no real moat, training data that can't scale, or architectures that won't integrate. How do you vet for technical quality?'
scenarios.ideal_response:
You're describing exactly why we exist. Surface-level AI is everywhere; defensible AI is rare.

Our technical vetting examines:
1. **Data moat** — Is training data proprietary? Can it scale? Legal to use?
2. **Architecture** — Custom models vs. API wrappers? Integration complexity?
3. **IP defensibility** — Patents, trade secrets, unique techniques?
4. **Team depth** — Research vs. engineering balance? Key-person risk?

We flag companies that are 'demo-ware' vs. genuinely differentiated. Our founder [name] spent [X years] at [relevant company] doing exactly this kind of technical DD.

Want to see how we profiled a recent asset? I can share our technical assessment methodology.

scenarios.situation: Marcus says: 'I've heard AI companies are getting crazy multiples — like 20-30x ARR. Is that realistic? I don't want to list and then find out buyers are offering 5x.'
scenarios.ideal_response:
Good to have this conversation upfront. Here's the reality:

20-30x ARR multiples exist but they're outliers — typically high-growth (100%+ YoY), strategic acquisitions by big tech, or bidding wars. Most AI company transactions are in the 5-12x range depending on growth, retention, and strategic value.

At $2M ARR, your multiple depends heavily on: growth rate, net retention, customer concentration, and how strategic you are to specific buyers.

Our job is to surface multiple buyers and create competitive tension — that's how you get fair value, not by anchoring to outlier headlines.

Want to walk through what realistic scenarios look like for PredictAI specifically?

persona.name: Robert Kim
persona.background: Leads AI bolt-on strategy for portfolio

scenarios.situation: Robert says: 'We're specifically looking for AI add-ons for our portfolio company DataStack. Need companies in data infrastructure with $1-3M ARR. Do you have anything that specific?'
scenarios.ideal_response:
That's exactly the kind of specific brief we work with. Data infrastructure + $1-3M ARR + add-on ready — narrow but we can work with it.

Let me check our current pipeline against those criteria. We may have 1-2 matches, and if not, we can proactively source against that thesis.

For DataStack specifically: What's the integration requirement? Are you looking for technology, team, or customer base primarily? That'll help us filter.

I'll come back to you within 48 hours with any relevant matches — anonymized profiles you can review before we go further.

scenarios.situation: Priya says: 'My biggest concern is what happens to my team in an acquisition. I've heard horror stories about acqui-hires where everyone gets laid off within a year. How do I protect them?'
scenarios.ideal_response:
That's a critical concern and it's good you're thinking about it early.

The outcome depends heavily on deal structure and buyer type:
- **Strategic acquirers** (building long-term) typically retain teams for integration
- **Acqui-hires** explicitly value the team — retention packages are standard
- **PE buyers** vary — some optimize, some grow

You have leverage here. Team retention commitments, earnouts tied to team staying, and vesting acceleration can all be negotiated.

We help founders navigate these terms. When we match you with buyers, we can filter for those with track records of keeping teams intact.

Want to discuss what protection mechanisms look like in practice?

persona.name: David Martinez
persona.background: Led 5 AI acquisitions in past 3 years

scenarios.situation: David says: 'We already have relationships with all the major AI VCs and see most deals through our network. I'm not sure a platform adds value for a buyer like us who's already well-connected.'
scenarios.ideal_response:
You're right that Adobe's network is extensive — and for deals that come through traditional channels, you don't need us.

Where we add value is different: off-market founders who don't want to broadcast they're exploring, companies outside the usual VC ecosystem (bootstrapped, international, niche verticals), and opportunities that aren't making the rounds.

We also handle initial screening and technical DD — so when an asset reaches you, it's pre-qualified against your criteria, saving your team's time.

The question isn't whether you see deals — it's whether you're seeing the right ones efficiently. Want me to show you a few current assets that haven't been shopped through traditional channels?

scenarios.situation: William says: 'We're interested in AI but we're not a typical buyer — we do longer holds, don't have integration teams, and prefer minority stakes sometimes. Do you work with investors like us?'
scenarios.ideal_response:
Absolutely — family offices are one of our five core buyer types, and your approach (longer holds, minority stakes possible) is actually attractive to certain founders.

Many AI founders prefer patient capital over quick flips. For companies not ready for full exit but wanting strategic partnership + capital, a family office stake can be ideal.

Our platform supports various transaction structures — not just full acquisitions. We can filter for companies open to minority investments and longer partnership horizons.

Want to discuss your specific criteria? I'd want to understand: check size range, sectors within AI, and level of involvement you typically want.

scenarios.situation: Kevin asks: 'I've never been through an M&A process before. What does the typical timeline look like from listing with you to actually closing a deal?'
scenarios.ideal_response:
Great question — setting realistic expectations is important.

Typical timeline from listing to close: 6-12 months. Here's the breakdown:

**Month 1-2:** Onboarding, vetting, building your asset profile
**Month 2-4:** Matching with buyers, initial introductions, NDAs
**Month 4-6:** Deeper conversations, data room access, preliminary offers
**Month 6-12:** LOI negotiation, due diligence, legal, close

Factors that speed things up: clear financials, clean cap table, motivated buyer, smaller deal size.

Factors that slow down: complex structures, multiple founders, regulatory considerations.

The confidential nature means you can run this process while continuing to operate normally — no disruption to your business.

Want to start with an initial consultation to assess where you'd fall on this timeline?

persona.name: Andrew Walsh
persona.background: Early-stage VC, portfolio includes 3 AI unicorns

scenarios.situation: Andrew says: 'My LPs expect 3x+ returns. Most M&A exits I've seen for AI companies at Series A stage end up being talent acquisitions at 1-2x. How do you help portfolio companies avoid that outcome?'
scenarios.ideal_response:
That's the right concern — acqui-hire pricing is the floor, not the goal.

How we help avoid 1-2x outcomes:

1. **Timing:** Engage when there's optionality, not desperation. Running out of runway = bad leverage.

2. **Positioning:** We help companies tell a strategic narrative, not a 'team for sale' story.

3. **Competition:** Surface multiple buyers simultaneously. Nothing kills acqui-hire pricing like a bidding war.

4. **Buyer selection:** Some acquirers (Google, Meta) default to talent acquisition. Others (mid-market strategics, PE) pay for the business.

For your portfolio specifically: companies 3-5 years post-Series A with real revenue are in the sweet spot — they have optionality and value beyond just team.

Want to discuss specific portfolio companies that might be approaching that window?

scenarios.situation: Nina says: 'A banker we talked to wanted 12-month exclusivity. I'm nervous about locking in with anyone for that long. What's your exclusivity requirement?'
scenarios.ideal_response:
We don't require exclusivity — at all.

Here's why: Exclusivity protects bankers, not founders. They want guaranteed commission even if they underperform.

Our model is different: Success-fee only means we only get paid if we deliver value. If you find a better path through your own network or another channel, that's fine — we haven't cost you anything.

You can work with us while keeping other options open. Many founders appreciate that flexibility, especially in healthcare AI where regulatory timelines and strategic buyer cycles are unpredictable.

The trade-off: We're selective about who we work with since we're taking the risk. But once we commit, we're fully aligned with your outcome.

Does that structure work better for what you're looking for?

persona.name: Rachel Torres
persona.background: Fast-moving data company, aggressive AI strategy

scenarios.situation: Rachel says: 'We move fast. When we see something we want, we can close in 60 days. But most deal sources waste our time with companies that aren't ready or willing. How do you qualify seller readiness?'
scenarios.ideal_response:
Speed matters to us too — wasting your time means wasting ours.

How we qualify seller readiness:

1. **Motivation:** We assess why they're exploring and confirm they're genuinely open to transactions, not just 'testing the market'

2. **Timeline:** Explicit conversation about their decision timeframe and board alignment

3. **Data room:** We don't introduce companies that can't provide clean financials, cap table, and technical documentation within 2 weeks

4. **Valuation expectations:** Pre-aligned on realistic ranges before introductions

For Snowflake specifically: When I send you a company, it means they're ready to engage seriously and can match your 60-day pace.

Want me to flag companies in our pipeline that meet your readiness criteria?

scenarios.situation: Tom asks: 'When do I have to tell my employees I'm exploring a sale? I don't want to deal with the anxiety and potential departures.'
scenarios.ideal_response:
Ideally: As late as possible, which is usually after LOI or during final diligence.

The confidential nature of our process means:
- Initial exploration: No one needs to know
- Buyer conversations: Still confidential
- LOI stage: Some disclosure may be needed (key employees, board)
- Final diligence: Broader team usually learns

That said, you control the timeline. Some founders bring in key lieutenants early for input. Others keep it to themselves until deal is nearly done.

The goal is avoiding months of uncertainty for your team. A compressed, well-managed disclosure is better than prolonged anxiety.

We can help you plan the communication strategy when the time comes. Want to discuss how other founders have handled this?

persona.name: Christina Lee
persona.background: Growth equity, focuses on AI/ML companies

scenarios.situation: Christina says: 'Our diligence process is extensive — 3-4 months minimum. We need detailed technical DD, customer references, financial verification. Do your companies actually have their house in order for that level of scrutiny?'
scenarios.ideal_response:
That level of diligence is exactly what serious buyers should do — and exactly why thorough vetting matters upfront.

Our onboarding process specifically prepares companies for institutional DD:

**Technical:** Architecture documentation, code quality assessment, data practices review
**Financial:** Verified via QuickBooks/Xero integrations, not just self-reported
**Customer:** We confirm reference-ability before listing
**Legal:** Cap table clean, IP assignments confirmed, no obvious landmines

Companies that can't meet these standards don't make it to our platform.

For Summit specifically: We can flag which companies in our pipeline have already passed institutional-grade vetting vs. those earlier in the process.

Want to see our DD checklist and discuss what 'Summit-ready' looks like?

scenarios.situation: James asks: 'How many buyers will you typically introduce me to? I want to make sure I have options, but I also don't want to run a circus.'
scenarios.ideal_response:
Typically 5-10 qualified introductions, but quality matters more than quantity.

Our approach:
1. **Initial matching:** We identify 15-20 potential fits based on your profile
2. **Curated outreach:** We approach the best-fit buyers with your anonymized teaser
3. **Qualified introductions:** Only buyers who express genuine interest after NDA get introduced

You control the pace. Some founders prefer sequential conversations (less overhead). Others want parallel processes (creates urgency).

The goal is 3-5 serious conversations, not 50 tire-kickers. Competition matters, but so does your time.

For AISecure specifically: Cybersecurity AI is hot right now. I'd expect strong interest from both strategics (Palo Alto, CrowdStrike) and PE. Want to discuss which buyer types make most sense?

scenarios.situation: Mark says: 'The last AI company we acquired took 18 months to integrate and the key engineers left. Technical debt was worse than disclosed. How do you vet for integration readiness?'
scenarios.ideal_response:
Integration failures like that are exactly why technical vetting matters — and why surface-level pitches are dangerous.

Our technical assessment specifically examines:

**Architecture:** Monolith vs. microservices, API design, dependency complexity
**Code quality:** Test coverage, documentation, technical debt indicators
**Team structure:** Key-person risk, knowledge distribution, flight risk factors
**Integration complexity:** What's required to work within your stack

We can't guarantee perfect integration — that depends on your team's execution too. But we can surface red flags early and give you honest assessment of complexity.

For ServiceNow specifically: What's your integration architecture? Understanding your target state helps us filter for companies that'll fit vs. fight your stack.

Want to review how we assessed a recent company's integration readiness?

scenarios.situation: Sarah asks: 'A buyer mentioned most of the deal value would be in an earnout tied to performance. That seems risky — what if they deliberately tank our metrics? How do I think about earnout structures?'
scenarios.ideal_response:
Valid concern — earnouts can be traps if structured poorly.

Key protections to negotiate:

**Control:** If earnout depends on metrics, you need operational control to hit them. Beware buyers who take control then set impossible targets.

**Definitions:** Crystal clear metric definitions. Revenue = what exactly? GAAP? Bookings? Specific products?

**Acceleration:** What happens if they sell the business or kill the product? You should get paid out.

**Cap:** Is there upside participation or just downside risk?

Healthy earnout structures:
- 50-70% at close (guaranteed value)
- 30-50% earnout tied to reasonable, controllable metrics
- 12-24 month timeframe (not 4 years)

Red flags: >50% in earnout, metrics you don't control, no acceleration clauses.

We help founders negotiate these terms. Want to walk through what a fair structure looks like for NLPWorks?
